terms.shortDefinition: NOI divided by property value, expressing the expected rate of return on an investment property as if purchased with all cash.
terms.fullDefinition: The Capitalization Rate (cap rate) is a fundamental metric for valuing income-producing real estate. It represents the expected return on investment if you purchased the property with all cash (no financing). Cap rate is calculated by dividing Net Operating Income (NOI) by property value. Higher cap rates indicate higher returns (but often more risk); lower cap rates suggest lower returns (but often more stability). Cap rates vary by market, property type, and asset class.

variables.description: Current market value or purchase price

proTips: Cap rates don't account for financing—use cash-on-cash return for leveraged returns
A property bought at 7% cap rate doesn't mean 7% return if you use financing
Cap rates compress (go lower) when interest rates drop and expand when rates rise
Compare cap rates within the same market and property type for meaningful analysis

examples.title: Comparing Investment Properties
examples.scenario: Property A: $400K, $32K NOI (8% cap). Property B: $500K, $35K NOI (7% cap)
examples.calculation: Property A cap rate = $32K ÷ $400K = 8%. Property B = $35K ÷ $500K = 7%
examples.outcome: Property A has a higher cap rate (better yield), but Property B might be in a better location with more appreciation potential

terms.shortDefinition: The estimated value of a property after all renovations and improvements are completed.
terms.fullDefinition: After Repair Value (ARV) is the projected market value of a property after renovations are complete. It's a critical number for fix-and-flip investors and BRRRR strategists. ARV is determined by analyzing comparable sales (comps) of renovated properties in the same area. The difference between purchase price plus rehab costs and ARV represents your potential equity gain.
proTips: Always verify ARV with recent comps—not listing prices, but actual sold prices
Be conservative with ARV estimates; overestimating is the #1 mistake new flippers make
Consider time on market for your ARV comps—slow sales suggest lower values
Your realtor or appraiser can help validate your ARV assumptions

examples.title: BRRRR Deal Analysis
examples.scenario: Property listed at $150K needs $40K in rehab. Comparable renovated homes sold for $280K
examples.calculation: ARV = $280K. Using 70% rule: ($280K × 0.70) - $40K = $156K max purchase price
examples.outcome: At $150K purchase, this deal works. Total investment: $190K. Equity at refinance (75% LTV): $210K loan = $20K profit + recycled capital

terms.shortDefinition: Recently sold properties similar to yours used to determine market value.
terms.fullDefinition: Comparable sales (comps) are recently sold properties that are similar to the subject property in location, size, condition, and features. Appraisers and investors use comps to estimate market value. Good comps are typically within 0.5-1 mile, sold within the last 6 months, and have similar square footage, bed/bath count, and condition. Adjustments are made for differences.
proTips: Look for 3-5 comparable sales for a reliable estimate
Sold prices matter more than listing prices—anyone can list at any price
Adjust for differences: add value for extra beds/baths, subtract for less
Drive the comps to verify condition matches what you expect for value

terms.shortDefinition: Property price divided by annual gross rent, used for quick property comparisons.
terms.fullDefinition: The Gross Rent Multiplier (GRM) is a simple metric for comparing investment properties. It's calculated by dividing the property price by annual gross rent. A lower GRM generally indicates a better value (you're paying less per dollar of rent). While GRM doesn't account for expenses like cap rate does, it's useful for quick screening and comparing properties in the same market.
proTips: Lower GRM = better value relative to income, but consider the why (condition? location?)
GRM doesn't account for expenses—a property with low taxes might look worse than one with high taxes
Use GRM for quick screening, then dig deeper with NOI and cap rate
GRM varies significantly by market—know your local benchmarks

terms.shortDefinition: A professional opinion of a property's market value, required by lenders for mortgage financing.
terms.fullDefinition: An appraisal is a professional estimate of a property's market value conducted by a licensed appraiser. Lenders require appraisals to ensure the property is worth at least the loan amount. Appraisers use three approaches: Sales Comparison (comps), Income Approach (for rentals), and Cost Approach (replacement cost). For investment properties, both the sales comparison and income approaches matter.
proTips: Provide the appraiser with your renovation receipts and a list of improvements
A low appraisal can derail a deal—have backup plans (renegotiate, bring more cash, or walk)
For refinances, meet the appraiser and walk them through the property
Appraisals for investment properties may use the income approach—make sure your rent roll is accurate

terms.shortDefinition: Increasing property value through improvements or increasing income, rather than waiting for market appreciation.
terms.fullDefinition: Forced appreciation is increasing a property's value through your own actions rather than waiting for the market to appreciate. For residential properties, this means renovations and upgrades. For income properties, it includes increasing NOI through higher rents or lower expenses—since value = NOI ÷ cap rate, higher NOI directly increases value. Forced appreciation is the foundation of value-add investing and the BRRRR strategy.
proTips: Every $1 increase in monthly NOI can add $150-200 to property value (at 6-8% cap rate)
Focus on improvements that increase rent or reduce expenses, not just cosmetics
Force appreciation before market conditions change on you
Combine forced appreciation with a refinance to recycle capital

examples.title: Forcing Appreciation Through NOI
examples.scenario: Your 4-unit property has NOI of $24K. In a 6% cap rate market, value = $400K. You raise rents by $100/unit.
examples.outcome: By increasing rent $100/unit, you created $80K in equity through forced appreciation
